The products for sale include: potatoes, wheat flour, condiments, firewood, etc. Mrs. Mariam I., the first person standing on the left in the photo, intends to buy cartloads of firewood in surrounding villages. She conducts her retail sales for cash to essentially women customers.

She expects to make average profits of 40,000 CFA francs per month. These profits will enable her to pay off her loan and also to help her husband with daily expenses.

loans.use: buy firewood

loans.name: Allakandeme Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe    ALLAKANDEME est constitué de 5 femmes toutes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de47 ans et7 enfants. Elles vivent  dans des familles nucléaires dans le quartier BOUNOUKOBOUGOU de la ville de Yanfolila. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et de commerce. Pour renforcer leur capacité financière afin de mieux faire leur commerce, elles ont adhéré à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elles sont à leur 14éme prêt. Les 13 précédents prêts ont été correctement remboursés. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de  condiments à l’image de NOUMOUSSO qui est la femme assise  dans la photo. Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, diverses quantités et sortes de condiments avec les grossistes  de Bougouni. Elle effectue ses ventes au marché  et à domicile, en détail au comptant et à crédit  à une clientèle mixte . 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 60.000FCFA qui sera  investi dans les activités et rembourser le prêt.
texts.en: The ALLAKANDEME group is made up of 5 women, all of whom are married with 7 children, and who are aged 47 on average. They live in nuclear families in the BOUNOUKOBOUGOU quarter of Yanfolila town. They met through neighbours, friends and business. In order to boost their working capital and better run their businesses, they joined the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance organisation, with whom they are on their 14th loan. The previous 13 have all been successfully repaid. This group of women sells condiments via Noumousso who is the woman sitting down in the photo. She aims to use her loan in order to purchase various quantities and types of condiments from the wholesalers of Bougouni. She sells her goods at the market and at home, to a mixed customer base. She aims to generate an average monthly revenue of 60,000 FCFA which will be reinvested into her business activities and used to repay the loan.

loans.use: to purchase condiments

loans.name: Badeya Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq  membres du groupe  BADEYA sont  des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans,  4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des  familles monogames au quartier Mancourani de la ville de Sikasso. 
Elles sont à leur dix-huitième prêt dans ce groupe qui évolue avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme   Safiatou  1 ère personne de la droite vers la gauche fait la vente de pagnes wax dans ce groupe de femmes. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  15 pièces de pagnes wax auprès des grossistes. Elle vend ses articles au grand marché et à la maison à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son interêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en:
The five members of the BADEYA group are married women who on average are 34 years of age with four children. They live mostly in monogamous families in the Mancourani district of the city of Sikasso.

The group is on its eighteenth loan in cooperation with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, to satisfy their customers' needs.

Ms. Safiatou, the first person from right to left, sells pagnes wax (a variety of colorful West-African cloth) in this group of women.

She intends to use the loan to buy 15 lengths of pagnes wax from wholesalers. She sells her products at the main market and from her home to a clientele of both women and men.

She expects average monthly profits of 40,000 CFA francs, a portion of which will be used to pay the loan and its interest and the remainder put into savings.

loans.use: buy pagnes (colorful West-African fabric)

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les sept  membres du groupe  DANAYA  sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de  33 ans et 3 enfants et vivant toutes dans des familles traditionnelles à   OUAYERMA I, un des quartiers de la 3ème région administrative du Mali (SIKASSO).
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités de commerce. 
Elles sont à leur 16eme prêt avec l’institution et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Les spéculations a vendre sont entre autres: l’encens, l’arachide, le bois de chauffe, les savons ,   etc.     AMINATA  1ère  personne à gauche de la photo position debout  compte acheter avec son prêt des condiment auprès des grossistes sur place et effectues ses ventes à une clientèle constituée essentiellement de femmes, en détail au comptant et quelques fois à crédit.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 80 000 francs CFA par mois.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Damaya group are married women who on average are 33 years old with three children. They all live in traditional families in Ouayerma I, one of the neighborhoods in the third administrative region of Mali (Sikasso).

They work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to carry out their trade activities. They are on their 16th loan with the institution and all previous loans have been repaid.

The products sold include: incense, peanuts, wood, soaps, etc. Aminata, the first person standing on the left of the picture, plans to use her loan to buy condiments from local wholesalers and conduct her retail sales to a customer base consisting mainly of women, for cash and sometimes on credit.

She expects to make average profits of 80,000 CFA francs per month. These profits will enable her to pay off her loan and also help her husband with daily expenses.

loans.use: buy condiments

loans.name: Annet

texts.en:
Annet is married with three children, and one goes to school. She has one additional family member (sister). She operates a grocery shop at the market on a retail basis. She has been in this business for three years. She works six days a week. 

She has applied for a loan of 1,100,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy sweets, sugar, rice, soap, biscuits, boxes of soap and cooking oil for her grocery. Her major business challenges include seasonality and transportation. She is aspiring of owning a fully stocked retail shop.   

She resides in a rented house, and the family has access to electricity but not piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy sweets, bags of sugar, soap, biscuits, boxes of soap and cooking oil.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  membres du groupe  BENKADI sont  essentiellement de femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogamiques au quartier Bougoula hameau un des quartiers périphérique  de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur treizième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme   ASSETOU fait la vente de pagnes wax  dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle est la troisième position debout  de la  gauche  vers la  droite sur la photo.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  50 pièces de pagnes wax. Elle vend ses articles au grand marché et à la maison. Elle vend au comptant à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’homme. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 85 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son interêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group are married women with an average age of 32 years and have an average of 3 children each. They mostly live in monogamous families in the Bougoula neighborhood, one of the surrounding neighborhoods of the city of Sikasso in the third administrative region of Mali. They are on their thirteenth loan with the microfinance organization Soro Yiriwaso, in the hope of meeting the needs of their customers.

Assetou is in the business of selling "pagne" cloth (the traditional colorful cloth of western Africa) in this group of women. She is pictured standing, third from left to right, in the photo. She plans to use her loan to purchase 50 pieces of wax "pagne" cloth. She sells her items at the big market and from her home. She sells for cash to a customer base made up of men and women. Assetou hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 85,000 francs CFA, a portion of which she will use to repay the loan and its interest, and the rest she will put into savings.

loans.use: to purchase "pagne" cloth

loans.name: Teriya Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe TERIYA ont en moyenne 40 ans, 5 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à  LAFIABOUGOU l’un des quartiers de la ville de SAN chef du cercle  cercle dans la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des produits alimentaires telle l’huile alimentaire. 
Après avoir correctement remboursés les prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe TERIYA sont à leur 3 eme  prêt solidaire. MARSELLINE  2 eme   femme debout de  la gauche vers la droite  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 70 litres d’huile alimentaires.  Elle s’approvisionne  sur place chez les grossistes à SAN. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la nourriture, l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the "Teriya" group are on average 40 years old with five children and all live in traditional extended households in Lafiabougou, one of the areas in the city of San, the main city in the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali.
These women know each other through family connections and run businesses buying and selling food products such as cooking oil.
After having properly repaid their previous loans, the women of the Teriya group are on their third solidarity (group) loan. Marselline, the woman standing second from the left in the photo, intends to use her loan to buy 70 litres of cooking oil. She gets her supplies locally from the wholesalers in San. She makes her sales to a clientele composed of men and women, in cash and often on credit.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 30,000 FCFA, which will be used to pay for expenses related to food, clothing, and education, with the rest being reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy oil

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe BENKADI ont en moyenne  33 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à   TOMINIAN  quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente des habillements, des grains de céréales, boissons, etc.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe BENKADI sont à leur  7 eme  prêt solidaire. FATOUMATA  2 eme   femme   debout de  la gauche vers la droite  compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter deux sacs de 100kgs de mil et 200kgs de maïs.  Elle s’approvisionne  sur place. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 40 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture, et l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of Benkadi Group average 33 years of age and four children. They all live in extended traditional families in Tominian, fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

The got acquainted through bonds of kinship, and their businesses consist in buying and selling clothes, cereals, beverages, etc.

After having repaid the previous loans without problems, they are now seeking their seventh solidarity loan (group loan).

Fatoumata, second woman from the left in the standing row, intends to use her loan to buy two 100-kg sacks of millet and 200 kg of corn.

She gets her supplies in Tominian, and sells for cash and often on credit, to a clientele comprising both women and men.

She foresees turning an average monthly profit of XOF 40'000 (ca US$ 83) to be used to cover expenses related to healthcare, food, clothes, and school. The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy 200 kg of millet and 200 kg of corn

loans.name: Kotognogontala Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  KOTOGNOTALA  sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogamiques au quartier Bougoula hameau un des quartiers périphérique  de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme  AMI fait la vente des condiments dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle est la  1 ère assise à droite sur la photo.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  30 paniers de tomates et 20 paquets de cube maggi. Elle vend ses articles au marché et à la maison au comptant à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 60 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son interêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The members of the Kotognogontala group are married women who, on average, are 32 years old and have four children. They live mostly in monogamous families in the Bougoula neighborhood, one of the outer areas of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. The group is on their ninth loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy their customers' needs.

In this group of women, Ami sells condiments. She is the first person seated on the right in the photo. With her loan she plans to buy 30 baskets of tomatoes and 20 packets of Maggi cubes. She sells these goods at a market and from home for cash to male and female customers. 

Ami hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 60,000 francs CFA, in which a part will be used to pay back the loan and the interest and the other part will be put in savings.

loans.use: to buy condiments

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en:
Margaret  is widowed with six children and three of her children go to school. She takes care of two additional family members (grandchildren). 

Margaret sells goats. She operates her business on a retail basis at the market. She has been in this business for many years. She works seven days a week. She gets additional income from rental houses. She has applied for a loan of Ugandan Shillings 1,000,000 from MCDT-SACCO to buy more goats for sale. 

Her major business challenges include seasonality and transportation. She aspires to build more rental houses and also to become a wholesaler. She resides in her own house and the family has access to electricity but do not have access to piped water. Her monthly expenses includes bills and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more goats for resale

loans.name: Sabougnouma Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe  SABOUGNOUMA  sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, et ont en moyenne  4 enfants. Elles vivent dans des  familles monogamiques au quartier Bougoula hameau un des quartiers périphérique  de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme  SANATA fait la vente des condiments dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle est debout au milieu.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt  20 paniers de tomates, 20 paquets de cube maggi et des courges. Elle vend ses articles à Sikasso au comptant à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’hommes. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 60 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son interêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The members of the Sabougnouma group are married women who, on average, are 32 years old and have four children. They live mostly in monogamous families in the Bougoula neighborhood, one of the outer areas of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. The group is on their ninth loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy their customers' needs.

In this group of women, Sanata sells condiments. She is standing in the middle [of the photo]. With her loan she plans to buy 20 baskets of tomatoes, 20 packets of Maggi cubes, and squash. She sells these goods in Sikasso for cash to male and female customers. 

Sanata hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 60,000 francs CFA, in which a part will be used to pay back the loan and the interest and the other part will be put in savings.

loans.use: to buy condiments

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Les 7 membres du groupe  Sinignessigui sont  des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 32 ans, et ont en moyenne  3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogamiques au quartier Bougoula hameau un des quartiers périphérique  de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur douzième prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme   Kadi  fait la vente de savons  dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle est debout en troisième position  de la  gauche  vers la  droite sur la photo.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt   20 sacs de savon kabocourouni. Elle vend ses articles au marché  et à la maison. Elle vend au comptant à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’homme. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 75 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son interêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The seven members of the Sinignessigui group are married women who, on average, are 32 years old and have three children. They live mostly in monogamous families in the Bougoula neighborhood, one of the outer areas of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. The group is on their 12th loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy their customers' needs.

In this group of women, Kadi sells soap. She is standing third from the left in the photo. With her loan she plans to buy 20 bags of kabocourouni soap. She sells these goods at a market and from home for cash to male and female customers. 

Kadi hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA, in which a part will be used to pay back the loan and the interest and the other part will be put in savings.

loans.use: to buy soap

loans.name: Sinignessigui Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe SINIGNESSIGUI ont en moyenne  31 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à   TOMINIAN dans la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font essentiellement  les activités d’achat et de vente des articles divers..
Après avoir correctement remboursés les prêts précédents, les femmes du groupe SINIGNESSIGUI sont à leur  7 eme  prêt solidaire. SARAN  2 eme   femme de  la droite vers la gauche compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter des parures pour les femmes, 20 d’huile, 20 paquets de cube Maggi, des oignons, des pommes de terre et des patates douces.  Elle s’approvisionne  sur place. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé,  à la nourriture, et l’habillement, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of Sinignessigui Group average 31 years of age and three children. They all live in extended traditional families in Tominian, fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali.

The got acquainted through bonds of kinship, and their businesses consist mainly in buying and selling various products.

After having repaid the previous loans without problems, they are now seeking their seventh solidarity loan (group loan).

Saran, second woman from the right, intends to use her loan to buy women's finery, 20 cans of cooking oil, 20 packs of Maggi bouillon cubes, onions, potatoes and sweet potatoes.

She gets her supplies in Tominian, and sells for cash and often on credit, to a clientele comprising both women and men.

She foresees turning an average monthly profit of XOF 30'000 (ca US$ 62) to be used to cover expenses related to healthcare, food, clothes, and school. The remainder will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy women's finery, cooking oil, bouillon cubes, onions, potatoes, and sweet potatoes

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Les HUIT  membres du groupe  SOUTOURA  sont essentiellement de femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 23 ans, et ont en moyenne  2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des  familles monogamiques au quartier Bougoula hameau un des quartiers périphérique  de la ville de Sikasso 3ème  région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt avec l’institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso, dans le souci de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle.
Mme  DIALIA  fait la vente des condiments dans ce groupe de femmes. Elle est la deuxième personne position assise de la  droite vers la gauche sur la photo.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt 20 litre d’huile  10 paniers de tomates, 5 paquets de cube maggi. Elle vend ses articles au marché et à la maison. Elle vend au comptant à une clientèle constituée de femmes et d’homme. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son interêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The eight members of the Soutoura group are mostly married women who, on average, are 23 years old and have two children. They live mostly in monogamous families in the Bougoula neighborhood, one of the outer areas of the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali. The group is on their first loan with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, in order to satisfy their customers' needs.

In this group of women, Dialia sells condiments. She is the second person seated from the right in the photo. With her loan she plans to buy 20 liters of oil, 10 baskets of tomatoes, and five packets of Maggi cubes. She sells these goods at a market and from home for cash to male and female customers. 

Dialia hopes to earn an average monthly profit of 20,000 francs CFA, in which a part will be used to pay back the loan and the interest and the other part will be put in savings.

loans.use: to buy condiments

loans.name: Nimy Group

texts.fr:
Les  femmes du groupe NIMY ont en moyenne 38 ans, 4 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à  LAFIABOUGOU l’un des quartiers de la ville de SAN dans la quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali.
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font  les activités d’achat et de vente de condiments, des grains de céréales, des habillements, etc.
 Les femmes du groupe NIMY sont à leur 1er  prêt solidaire. RABAHAN  1ère    femme à la droite  sur la photo  compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 10 litres d’huile, 10 kg d’oignons frais, 10 kg oignons sèches,10 paquets de cube maggi.  Elle s’approvisionne sur place chez les grossistes à SAN. Elle effectue ses ventes, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes en espèce et souvent à crédit.
Elle envisage réaliser  un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses relatives à la santé, aux frais scolaires et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités.
texts.en:
The women of the "Nimy" group are on average 38 years old with four children and live in traditional extended households in Lafiabougou, one of the areas of the city of San in the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali.
These women know each other through family connections and run businesses buying and selling condiments, cereals, clothing, etc.
The women of the Nimy group are on their first solidarity (group) loan. Rabahan, the woman all the way on the right in the photo, intends to use her loan to buy 10 litres of oil, 10 kg of fresh onions, 10 kg of dried onions, and 10 packets of Maggi cubes. She gets her supplies locally from wholesalers in San. She makes her sales to a clientele composed of women and men in cash and often on credit.
She foresees realizing an average monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA which will be used to pay of expenses related to health and education, with the remainder being reinvested in her business.

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is married with three children who all go to school. She also takes care of her niece. She has a beauty salon, a business that she has been doing for 18 years. She has applied for a loan of 800,000 Ugandan shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more weaves, braids and cream relaxers. 

She generates additional income by selling used clothes and hiring out her motorcycle. She works at the market every week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and ever increasing prices of cosmetics in Uganda. She aspires to own a fully-stocked beauty salon and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house.  She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity, but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more weaves, braids and cream relaxers.

loans.name: Maa Kalijai Mahila Self Help Group.

texts.en: In 2009, 12 women from the small village of Balugaon stepped out, decided to build a secure future for their families and formed a group named Maa Kalijai Mahila Self Help Group. The members of Maa Kalijai Mahila Self Help Group are all women from the district of Khurda in Odisha, India. One of them is Posi, who was selected as their president. The lady in the picture seated second from the right is Posi. Posi is 30 years old and lives with her husband and her two children. Her husband is a farmer and has been involved in the activity of cultivation for a long time. She got the idea of doing vegetable cultivation from her husband, so she gathered some other women from her neighborhood and told them about her plan. They liked her idea and appreciated her. She took over the leadership of the group and started to cultivate vegetables and sell them in her village. Initially, she started growing only a few vegetables like potatoes, tomatoes, and onions but later on she grew bitter gourd, snake gourd, cucumbers, ladyfingers and brinjal (eggplant). She has a very good relationship with her customers as the vegetables she sells are fresh. Now she has a new idea to purchase some more land for cultivation so that she can grow more vegetables on a  larger scale. For this reason, she has requested a loan. She will use the loan to purchase land, seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: To purchase land, seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Suryoswara Shg Group

texts.en:
The responsible Suryoswara Self Help Group is made up of nine members. The members of Suryoswara Self Help Group are all women from the district of Khurda in Odisha, India. All of the group members are engaged in different activities. 

One of them is Jayanti, who was selected as their president. The lady first from the right is Jayanti. Jayanti is a 45-year-old living with her husband and two children. She is engaged in the activity of making leaf plates and bowls woven out of dry leaves. She sells them in the nearby market. These plates are used for different purposes, mainly for serving food. She makes different types and sizes of plates, depending upon the demand of her customers. 

She has requested a loan for purchasing machinery by which she can weave the plates more frequently and quickly; also, raw materials like leaves, thread, glue and plastic. She has a very good relation with her customers because she completes their orders on time.

Jayanti has a dream to make her children educated, and she is saying, "I am very thankful to Kiva for helping and supporting my group."

loans.use: to purchase a machine by which she can weave the plates more frequently and quickly; also, raw materials like leaves, thread, glue and plastic for her plate business.

loans.name: Francisco Wilfredo

texts.es:
Francisco de 27 años de edad, es una persona que se dedica a la elaboración de pan francés y aprendió cuando estaba cursando su bachillerato, porque hasta ahí estudio, actualmente está acompañado vive con su compañera de vida  y su hija que está recién nacida.

El trabajo de Francisco, es la venta y elaboración de pan francés que luego es vendido en los cantones más cercanos de donde vive y tiene sobre 3 años de dedicarse a este negocio, el cual le está dando ingresos para su familia y esto de hacer pan lo aprendió gracias a la ayuda de un amigo el cual tenía su panadería y Francisco en su tiempo libre después del estudio vendía pan en una bicicleta, y en el tiempo que estuvo ahí aprendió hacer pan y es así como con el tiempo que decidió iniciar con su propio negocio, en donde en un inicio sentía difícil; porque no tenía clientela y como era sus primeros, pasos en la elaboración del pan por si solo sentía temor a quemar el pan u otras cosas, pero con el tiempo fue superando todo ese temor y hoy en día es la única actividad que se dedica. En la elaboración del pan le ayuda un hermano y para distribuir el producto debe salir en su carro a venderlo de casa en casa y cada día recorre unos 15 kilómetros para vender su pan francés.

El dinero del préstamo será,  para comprar materia prima para la elaboración de pan, en donde comprara 8 bolsas de harina, una caja de manteca, una bolsa de levadura que son materiales indispensables para hacer el rico pan francés.

Francisco,  es una persona muy trabajadora y responsable que espera en un futuro poder mejorar, las instalaciones de donde tiene la panadería y crecer más con el negocio comprando más materia prima y poder tener mejores condiciones para su familia y su hija.
texts.en:
Francisco is 27 years old and makes his living by making French bread. He learned this skill while he was in high school. Francisco currently is in a relationship and lives with his life companion and their newborn daughter.

Francisco’s work involves making French bread and then selling it in the cantons that are closest to where he lives. He has been in this business for approximately three years and it has allowed him to earn income for his family. Francisco learned to make bread thanks to the help of a friend who has a bakery. In his free time, Francisco would sell bread after school by traveling on his bicycle. Eventually he learned to make bread, which led to his decision to start his own business. It was difficult at first because he had no customers. When he made bread by himself for the first time, he was afraid of burning the bread or some other problem. Francisco was able to overcome his fear and now this is the only activity to which he devotes his time. He makes the bread with the help of a brother and then distributes it by traveling in his car and going house to house. Each day he travels approximately 15 kilometers in order to sell French bread.

The money from the loan will be used to buy supplies for making bread, including eight bags of flour, a case of shortening, and a bag of yeast. These items are essential for making delicious French bread.

Francisco is a hardworking and responsible person who hopes to improve in the future the premises where his bakery is located. He also wants to grow his business even more, purchase more supplies, and provide better conditions for his family and his daughter.

loans.use: to buy flour, shortening, and yeast.

loans.name: Banco Mujer La Amistad Group

texts.es: Karla es la presidenta de Banco Mujer La Amistad, un grupo con una amplia trayectoria en Fundación Mujer, marcada por el compromiso y la puntualidad. Está compuesto por 5 socias, que invierten sus préstamos en actividades agropecuarias. Karla tiene 30 años, es jefa de hogar, y tiene 3 hijos, todos menores de edad, la hija mayor estudia en secundaria y los menores en primaria. Ella se dedica al desarrollo y engorde de cerdos, emprendimiento que inicio hace muchos años, y del que tiene mucha experiencia, se ha beneficiado con 3 préstamos anteriormente por parte de Fundación Mujer, y es la herramienta que le ha permitido consolidar su microempresa para poder cubrir todos los gastos básicos de su familia, además de su estudios ya que ella está estudiando en un instituto un curso para principiantes de estética, esto le va a permitir obtener un ingreso extra para mejorar la calidad de vida de ella y su familia. Que es su mayor deseo.
texts.en:
Karla is the president of Banco Mujer La Amistad, a well-established group within Fundación Mujer that is known for its commitment and punctuality. It is made up of 5 members, who invest their loans in agriculture and livestock. Karla is 30 years old, the head of her household and has 3 children all of whom are minors. Her eldest daughter is in secondary school and the younger children are in primary school. 

She works in raising and fattening pigs, an undertaking she started many years ago, and in which she has much experience. She has benefited from 3 previous loans through Fundación Mujer, and these loans are the tools that have allowed her to consolidate her small business in order to pay for her basic family needs. It has also allowed her to pay for her courses in an institute to become an esthetician. This will allow her to earn an extra income to improve the quality of life for her and her family, which is her ultimate dream.

loans.use: to purchase a big sow and piglets, as well as their feed and vitamins.

loans.name: Maa Tarini Self Help Group (C)

texts.en:
Ranjita is a 27-year-old lady who lives with her husband, parents-in-law and a six-year-old child in a small village in Odisha, India. In the picture, the lady standing second from right in the green sari in the front row is Ranjita. She is engaged in paddy cultivation. Her husband is doing the same business.

Some years ago, Ranjita formed a group with nine other women from her village with the group name of "Maa Tarini Self Help Group". All the group members are engaged in different business activities like selling milk, vegetable cultivation, etc to alleviate their poverty. Ranjita is the president of this group. She motivated all the group members to form this group so they could help and support each other in their business and personal lives.

Ranjita, along with her group, requested a loan of 150,000 INR. She will use her portion to purchase standard quality seeds and fertilizers for her paddy cultivation.

She hopes to build a house for her family and she is very grateful to Kiva for this opportunity.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and fertilizers for her paddy cultivation.

loans.name: Banco Mujer Fuerzas Unidas Group

texts.es: Keilyn es integrante de Banco Mujer Fuerzas Unidas un grupo compuesto por 9 socias, todas muy trabajadoras y responsables que se dedican a actividades agropecuarias y de pequeña industria. Keilyn de 30 años, es casada y madre de tres niños, 2 de ellos estudiantes de primaria. Su esposo trabaja en una finca bananera, y ella se dedica a trabajar en una pequeña parcela propia donde cría cerdos, pollos y cultiva algunas hortalizas. Keiliyn trabaja muy duro todos los días, debe levantarse muy temprano para atender sus labores domésticas, atender a sus niños, luego ir a trabajar en el campo, y como si fuera poco, por las tardes estudia, está sacando su bachillerato por madurez. Este es su segundo crédito y lo va a invertir en la compra de más cerdos para desarrollo y engorde, así como sus alimentos y vitaminas. El primer crédito fue de mucha ayuda ya que le permitió reforzar su negocio y con eso cubrir los gastos de los estudios de ella y sus hijos. Las metas a futuro de esta señora tan emprendedora es completar la secundaria, estudiar computación, y aumentar su patrimonio.
texts.en:
Keilyn is a member of the Mujer Fuerzas Unidas [United Strong Women], which has eight other hardworking and trustworthy members who work in ranching and small industry. Keilyn is 30, married, and the mother of three children, two of whom are in elementary school. Her husband works on a banana plantation. Keilyn manages a small plot of land that she owns and where she raises pigs, chickens, and grows several crops.

Keilyn works hard every day, and must get up early to do chores in her home, care for her children, and then go to work in the fields. She comes home in the evening and studies for her GED, as if this were an easy task.

Keilyn is in her second loan cycle and will invest these loan funds in the purchase of more pigs to grow and fatten, as well as the animals' food and vitamins. Keilyn's first loan helped her a great deal as it allowed her to make her business stronger and thus meet her children's educational expenses. The ambitions of this extremely entrepreneurial woman are to complete high school, then study computer science, and increase her wealth.

loans.use: to purchase pigs to raise and fatten, as well as the animals' food and vitamins

loans.name: Esperanza

texts.es:
Esperanza 
Sarapiqui
¢ 600.000


Esperanza es una mujer nicaragüense de 47 años, persona esforzada y trabajadora; tiene 6 hijos, 2 menores de edad viven con ella actualmente, por lo que ha dejado de trabajar fuera del hogar y desde hace 3 años inició su propio negocio para poder atenderlos y además apoyar económicamente al hogar, su esposo trabaja como peón agrícola en una finca cercana. Con su carácter emprendedor se ha capacitado en la cría de pollos de engorde, tiene suficiente  espacio en su parcela por lo que presenta el proyecto para  iniciar la crianza de estas aves y así crecer en su microempresa. Otra actividad que desarrolla es la  venta de queso,  que le compra a una proveedora de un poblado vecino. Ella ha logrado diversificar su negocio y ayudar a sus hijos en el estudio.
 Inicia con ahorro y una liquidación de su trabajo anterior; empezó comprando cantidades pequeñas de queso y al día de hoy vende cerca de 50 Kilos por semana. Logró comprar una refrigeradora para su almacenamiento y empezó a capacitarse en el manejo de pollos de engorde. Desea diversificar su negocio solicitando este préstamo para iniciar esta actividad, ya que investiga y descubre un mercado potencial en la zona, vendiendo a pequeños negocios de comida y vecinos.
 La microempresa cuenta con una  actividad consolida, que le generan ingresos para reinvertir y además cubrir ciertas obligaciones del hogar. El queso que distribuye está bien almacenado y se distribuye de forma semana, cuenta con una clientela fija y ofrece producto de calidad. Mantiene una recuperación constante y un buen manejo de su negocio. Tiene el espacio y el tiempo para incursionar en la actividad de los pollos.
texts.en:
Esperanza, Sarapiqui, 600,000 colones [CRC]

Esperanza, 47, is a strong and hardworking Nicaraguan woman.  She has six children.  Two minor children currently live with her, so she stopped working outside the home and started her own business three years ago to be able to take care of them as well as support the household financially.  Her husband works as a day laborer on a nearby farm.  

Because of her enterprising spirit she has trained to raise chickens to fatten.  She has enough room on her plot of land, so she's proposing the project to start raising poultry and grow in her micro-enterprise.  Another job is selling cheese, which she buys from a supplier in a neighboring community.  She has managed to diversify her business and help her children with their education.

Esperanza started with savings and a liquidation from her previous job.  She bought small quantities of cheese and now sells about 40 kilos a week.  She managed to buy a refrigerator for storage and began to train in managing chickens for fattening.  She wants to diversify her business by requesting this loan to invest in this job.  She looked into it and discovered a potential market in the area, selling to neighbors and small food businesses.

Her small business has an established job that generates income to reinvest as well as to cover certain household obligations.  The cheese she distributes weekly is well stored.  She has steady customers and sells a quality product.  She maintains a constant recovery and manages her business well.  She has the room and the time to get into the work with chickens.

loans.use: to invest in buying chickens and selling cheese

loans.name: Tagari

texts.en:
Tagari is a housewife of 42 years old, and she is married to Kokil, 51 years old. Kokil is working as a confectioner in the small village of Magurmari in Dhupguri. He has his own sweet shop, yet he is unable to cover the daily expenses for their family. 

They have two daughters getting higher education. One is doing a B.A. (Bachelor of Arts), and the other one is in class XII (grade 12). In spite of poverty, Tagari is a dedicated and tenacious mother to help her children to go ahead with their education.

Unfortunately, she cannot afford her daily family expenses as well as the educational expenses of her children with the current business of her husband. She decided to help her husband financially and applied for a loan of 15,000INR from Kiva’s partner, BJS, to buy potato seeds and fertilizers for growing potatoes on her own plot of land. She has chosen this profitable business to increase her family’s income by selling the crops in her local market. Potatoes are in great demand in rural areas.

She is thankful to BJS and Kiva for this loan.

loans.use: to purchase good-quality potato seeds and fertilizers to cultivate potatoes.

loans.name: Annapurna Mm Self Help Group

texts.en:
Annapurna MM Self Help Group is made up of fifteen women from a small village of Odisha, India. All the members of this group are involved in different activities such as betel leaf cultivation, milk selling, paddy and vegetable cultivation, etc. They are very hardworking women having a willingness to learn new business trends.They all help and support each other. Whatever they are earning from their businesses is used for their monthly household expenses.One of the group members "Kabita" is the president of this group. The lady standing first from left in the front row is Kabita.

Kabita is 35 years old and lives with her husband, parents-in-law and child aged eight years. She does betel leaf cultivation. She produces betel leaf and sells it at the market. Her husband is a farmer. Her husband helps Kabita in betel leaf selling at the market. Kabita is planning to buy standard quality seeds, fertilizers and pesticides so she can produce more betel leaf and can increase her income.

Kabita, along with her group members, is asking for a loan amount of 225,000 INR to invest in their business activities. Kabita will use her portion to purchase standard quality seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides for her betel leaf cultivation.

She wants to construct a house for her family. She says, on the behalf of the group members, "Thank you, KIVA, for providing this opportunity for us!"

loans.use: To purchase standard quality seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides for her betel leaf cultivation

loans.name: Baba Sainath Mahila Shg Group

texts.en:
Kanakalata is 37-year-old lady who lives with her husband and two children in a small village of Odisha, India. Her children are in school. She is engaged in mushroom cultivation. 

Kanakalata, along with seven women from her village, made a self-help group having name "Baba Sainath Mahila SHG" to educate each other in their business activities. All the group members are engaged in different activities like paddy cultivation, vegetable cultivation, flower selling, etc. All group members help and support each other in their personnel lives as well as in their business activities.

In the picture, the lady standing in the yellow sari is Kanakalata. She has been doing mushroom cultivation for four years. She produces mushrooms and then sells them. Her husband is a farmer and he does paddy and vegetable cultivation. Kanakalata's husband helps her in her activity and he also helps her to sell mushrooms in the market.

She and her group members have requested a loan amount of 80,000 INR for their business activities. Kanakalata will use her portion to purchase  standard quality seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides for her mushroom cultivation.

All the group members are very happy and excited to take this opportunity and also they are very thankful to Kiva for this.

loans.use: To purchase standard quality seeds, fertilizers and pesticides for her mushroom cultivation.

loans.name: Ahesha

texts.en:
Ahesha, age 48 years, and her husband, Abdul, age 54, live together with their four children in a kaccha house (made of straw and mud) in a small village of Magurmari in Dhupguri. Three of the children are school-goers, and one is working in the potato storage.

Ahesha is a housewife and her husband is a farmer. Both of them are illiterate and only know how to sign their names. Throughout the day, both of them are struggling hard for their earnings, but their financial condition is very poor. 

In spite of being a rustic woman, Ahesha took the initiative to contribute to her family so that they can overcome the economic problems. She decided to take a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to purchase potato seeds and fertilizers for potato farming, and sells those potatoes in the village market. 

She hopes their poverty may come to an end with this business. It will be possible for her to make a pakka (concrete) house in the future. She will be grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers for growing potatoes.

loans.name: Santi

texts.en:
Santi, her husband Shibmohan, and her two children stay at Altagram in the small town of Dhupguri in Jalpaiguri district. Santi, age 43, and her husband, age 46, are both illiterate, only knowing how to sign their names. Both of their daughters are going to college for higher education. 

Santi herself is a hardworking labourer, and her husband has been farming for many years to run their family. Being a hardworking and tenacious labourer, her income is not much sufficient to cover the expenses of their family, and so she decided to take the loan from BJS, an organization helping poor women of rural areas. 

She needs the loan to start her potato cultivation with her husband on the same land, so that they can grow many varieties of crops and vegetables to sell in the village market. There is a great demand for potatoes in the rural area. 

Santi wants to give higher education to her children with the profit from her business.

loans.use: to purchase potato seeds for growing potatoes and other vegetables on her own farmland.

loans.name: Haleema

texts.en:
Haleema is 43 years old and her husband Anarul is 51 years old. Haleema, Anarul and their two children live in a kaccha house (made of straw and mud) in the small village of Altagram in Dhupguri. Haleema’s husband is a farmer. Haleema passed her madhyamik examination (grade 10) and her husband studied up to class VII (grade 7). One of their sons is working as a mason and another son helps his father in farming vegetables. 

Haleema is employed in a private office and earns money to give support to her family, yet their economic condition is not running smoothly because her home expenses are gradually increasing day by day. She is still struggling to cover her family’s basic needs. 

Now Haleema decided to start her own potato business. She heard that Kiva’s partner, BJS, offers loan to the rural women to start new business. She applied for the loan to start potato cultivation with her husband on their farmland. The loan will help her to buy potato seeds and fertilizers to grow potatoes and after the harvest, she will sell those at the market. She knows that economic development is needed for a family so she is working hard. Haleema is very much thankful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Sarubala

texts.en:
Sarubala is a 47-year-old housewife who is illiterate and can only sign her name.  She lives with her husband, Nani, and her two children (one son and one daughter) in the small village of Kathalbari in Maynaguri in the district of Jalpaiguri.  Both the children are receiving an education. Her son is in college and her daughter goes to school and reads in class XII (Grade 12).

Sarubala's husband is 52 years old and passed 10th standard (Grade 10). He has been in the milk supply and milk products business for a long time. He has only one cow whose products he sells at the market, be it milk or curds and paneer. This does not generate enough income to give financial support to his family.

Sarubala has requested a loan from BJS to buy a cow for their existing milk supply business. It would give them the opportunity to sell more products and receive a greater income for the family. With her dedication and perseverance, Sarubala would like to keep working hard to make the business more profitable and to make all her dreams a reality. She dreams of upgrading their poor financial condition, providing a successful future for her children and building a pacca house (concrete made). She is grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Shefali

texts.en:
Shefali is a 23-year-old housewife who is married to 31-year-old Sachin. They live in the village of Altagram in Dhupguri. Her husband farms many kinds of seasonal vegetables on their land. They are illiterate, but know how to sign their names. They have two children. One goes to school, and the other is too small to go to school. 

Now Shefali decided to farm beans on their plot of land and sells that harvest to the wholesale market. She applied for a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to buy bean seeds, manure, pesticides, etc. to grow fresh beans on her farmland.

They live in a kaccha house, which is made of straw and mud. In the future, she dreams to make it a pakka (concrete) house. Shefali is a beloved mother as well as helpful; she is always ready to take on any kind of challenges for her family. She is now always emphasizing the improvement of her family’s economic condition and on their standard of living. That is why the loan is the way to her success.

loans.use: to buy seeds and manure for growing beans on her own land.

loans.name: Sunati

texts.en:
Sunati is a 27-year-old married woman from a small village of Dhupguri in Jalpaiguri district. She lives with her husband, Niranjan, and her two children. Both Sunati and her husband passed class V (grade 5) standard. Their children are studying in class IV (grade 4). She is very ambitious to give her children a bright future as well as higher education.

She works as a daily laborer, and her husband is a farmer. He has his own land where he farms different vegetables in different seasons and supplies them to the wholesale market or sells them in the local market. 

Now Sunati plans to take a loan to invest in potato farming by buying necessary supplies like potato seeds, fertilizers, urea, pesticides, etc. Sunati, being an enterprising and knowledgeable woman, gave preference to potato cultivation due to its necessity year-round. Potatoes are used in most of the Indian dishes irrespective of caste. 

Sunati is optimistic that she will earn more profits through this business.

loans.use: to purchase necessary supplies like potato seeds, fertilizers, urea, etc. for potato cultivation.

loans.name: Promila

texts.en:
Promila lives in the remote village of South Mouyamari in Maynaguri in the district Jalpaiguri. She is 39 years old, married, and is a housewife.  She lives with her husband and two sons in their own house.  Both Promila and her husband Jagadish are illiterate and can only sign their names. But they are providing education to both their sons. The elder one is in college and the younger is studying in Grade 9.

About five years ago, Promila's husband started a piggery business, where he breeds, raises and cares for pigs.  His business runs very well.  Jagadish sells his pigs in the market and in his neighborhood when they grow up. He also sells pork in the market. Promila, though a housewife, helps her husband in his work, after managing household works.  They have chosen this business as it is a profitable one and pork has a great demand in the local market. 
Promila and her husband want to extend their business, and for that they need some capital so Promila has requested a loan to buy more piglets to improve the business and generate more revenue.

She hopes for BJS and Kiva's cooperation. By funding this loan, she will be able to improve her business and at the same time improve her family's income to give financial sustenance and a good education to her sons.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to expand their existing piggery business

loans.name: Protima

texts.en:
Protima, 24 years old, is married with two children (one son and one daughter). She lives in the small village of Nirendrapur in Maynaguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. She can only sign her name. Her husband Sajon, 32 years old, is a farmer by profession.  He completed his primary education. One of their children is going to school and reads in class III (Grade 3). The other is below school-going age. They have a small kachha house (mud and straw made).

Protima's husband started a vegetable farming business on his inherited land.  Over the course of his five years in business, he was not able to earn much profit due to the lack of capital. Being a housewife, after managing her household work, Protima also helps her husband in his agricultural activities.  They sell their agricultural products (beans, onions, tomatoes, green chilies etc.) in the local market, and it is the only means of income to run the family
.   
Protima wants to help her husband by investing some money in his agricultural business.  She has taken a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to purchase potato seeds and manure with the loan to grow potatoes on their inherited land. They will sell their yield in the local market because potatoes are in demand in the present market.

The business will enable her to pull through financial hardships.  She aspires to buy another plot of land with the profits in the future. She is grateful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase good quality potato seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Purnima

texts.en:
Purnima is a resident of the small village of Nirendrapur in the district of Jalpaiguri.  She is 36 years old, married and the mother of two sons. Her oldest son is engaged in agriculture and the youngest is a student of class XII (Grade 12). Purnima is a homemaker and her husband is a farmer. Both of them are illiterate and can only sign their names.

Purnima's husband inherited land from his ancestors where he grows tea saplings. Their elder son is also engaged in this business. Purnima also helps them.  But the income from this business is not sufficient to cover all the expenses incurred by their family.

Purnima has decided to help her husband to overcome this financial hurdle.  She came to know about Kiva’s partner, BJS, and has taken a loan to expand their business.  She will use the loan to purchase tea saplings and good fertilizers to cultivate tea in large quantity.  As tea is very famous in India, they hope to have a great profit from this business.

Her goal is to give economic stability to her family with the extra income she will generate from the business. She also hopes to give a better education to her child.

She gives her thanks to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase tea saplings and fertilizers

loans.name: Suchitra

texts.en:
Suchitra is 37 years old, married and a housewife from the small village of Petkati in Moynaguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. She has completed secondary education (Grade 10). She is blessed with two daughters. She has her own pacca house (concrete made). She lives there with her husband. Her husband Rakesh, 47 years old, is engaged in an agricultural business. He has an education up to Grade 10.  Their two daughters are married.

Suchitra's husband works very hard to support his family, but his earnings are not enough to cover the expenses of the family. Suchitra is planning to start her own sewing business at home. She knows how to sew. She will sew beautiful dresses for woman and sell those to the local garment shops. 

She applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS to purchase a sewing machine to start her business. Her customers will be her neighbors, relatives and friends and as well as the local garment shops. She hopes she will be able to increase her work, and therefore, increase her earnings to offer her family better living conditions.

Her full thanks go to her lenders, BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine to start her own business.

loans.name: Shipra

texts.en:
Shipra, 45 years old, is a married woman and mother of one daughter.  She is from the rural village of Moynamapara in the district of Jalpaiguri. She attended school up to grade 12. Her daughter goes to school and reads in class III (Grade 3).  Her husband Sajal is a graduate. He runs a sweetmeat shop.

Shipra's husband was the only earner in the family. It was very tough for Shipra to manage her household needs with her husband's small income. Therefore, she decided to help her husband with her earnings.  For this reason, she started a business selling clothing.  She has a small shop adjacent to her house. She buys different varieties of garments (sarees, salwar kamijs, frocks, shirts etc.) from the wholesale market and sells in her area.  Her neighbors, relatives and friends are her main customers.  Now she is playing an important role by giving financial support to her family.

With the growing needs of her family and the increasing educational expenses of her child, she wants to expand her business. She applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS to buy a wide variety of clothing of different colors and designs to attract more customers and expand her inventory.

Shipra is a successful entrepreneur. She expects a boost in her earnings with her loan and her plans are to use the profit of her business on the betterment of her family members and to go ahead with her business.

She is grateful to BJS and Kiva for this loan.

loans.use: To buy a wide variety of clothing to sell

loans.name: Rajasri

texts.en:
Rajasri  is a hardworking and ambitious woman. She is 42 years and raising two children (one son and one daughter) together with her husband Pulok, who is 48 years old.  Both Rajasri and her husband are well educated. Rajasri is a science graduate and her husband is an Arts graduate. Both of them are service-holders and are working in the private sector. Their son is in university and their daughter goes to school in Grade 8. They live in their own house in Moynaguri in the district Jalpaiguri.

Unfortunately their income is not enough to cover the family's necessities. Rajasri is very energetic and wishes to generate additional income to provide for the well-being of her family.  She requested a loan from Kiva’s partner, BJS, to start an Internet Cafe.  She needs money to add personal computers to her cafe.  Rajasri hopes that her project will be lucrative. It should appeal to the youngsters as the majority of the local people still do not have personal computers and access to an internet connection at home. Her son is also ready to assist her in her business.

She hopes this business will help her to improve the family's living conditions in the future.

She gives her thanks to BJS and Kiva for this loan.

loans.use: To buy computers  to start up an Internet Cafe.

loans.name: Swapna

texts.en:
Swapna is a 22-year-old married woman. She is from a rural area in Magurmari in the district of Jalpaiguri.  She attended school up to class VII (grade 8). She is raising two daughters together with her husband. Both the daughters are below the school-going age.

Swapna's husband, Santu, is 26 years old. He has completed primary education. He is engaged in a business of making 'Jarda' (a locally made mouth freshener). His earnings are too little to run a family well. Swapna is a housewife, raising her children, doing all the household work. She is a very energetic and hardworking woman.  

She runs an animal husbandry business, after managing all the work of her family.  As an extra means of income, Swapna works with livestock, a business that she started five years ago to give her husband financial support, thanks to her persistent work.

With an aim to develop her business, Swapna applied for a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to purchase a goat to increase the number of livestock. She plans to invest the income from the loan in further increasing the number of livestock to give her family a decent lifestyle. She also plans to save money for the education of her children.

loans.use: to purchase a goat for her animal husbandry.

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Rita is a 27-year-old rural woman. She is married and has two daughters. One of the daughters reads in class V (Grade 5), and the other is below school-going age. Rita attended school up to class VIII (Grade 8). Her husband Nibas is engaged in a small business. He is 40 years old and received education up to class X (Grade 10). They have their own house in Maynaguri in the district of Jalpaiguri.

Rita started her clothing business a few years back. Her husband's income was too low, so to give financial sustenance to her family she started this business. She began her business because she wanted to become self-employed, which helps in the smooth running of her home. 

She came to know about BJS (a Kiva partner) and applied for this loan. She wants to purchase more clothing like sarees, frocks, and ladies' dresses with the loan.  Moreover she wants to stock woolen garments for the coming winter season.

Rita plans to upgrade her own house to a pacca house (concrete made), to build a shop for business expansion, and to educate her children up to university level. She thanks BJS and Kiva for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing for her garment retail business.

loans.name: Chhaya

texts.en:
Chhaya is a 49-year-old woman. She is the mother of two children (one son and one daughter). She is married to Monoronjon, who is 57 years old. Chhaya completed her primary education and her husband studied up to class X (Grade 10). Their daughter is receiving an education and reads in class X (Grade 10).  Their son is engaged in a small business. They live in the small town of Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri in their own kachha house (mud and straw made).

Chhaya's husband established a clothing business five years ago. She began to assist her husband, after managing all the household work, in settling their domestic bills.  They purchase clothes from the wholesale market and sell them at retail. Their main customers are their neighbors, including both men and women. Now, it has become difficult to maintain their family with so little income due to the increasing prices of essential commodities.  So they want to expand their business.

Chhaya applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS in order to buy more clothing (sarees, frocks, shirts, etc).  Moreover, she wants to stock woolen garments for the upcoming winter season. She hopes that this loan will increase her profit margin.

She is thankful to both lenders (BJS and Kiva).

loans.use: To purchase more clothing to sell

loans.name: Meherun

texts.en:
Meherun, 31 years old, lives in Altagram in Dhupguri with her husband Abutaher, age 37, and their three children. She has read up to class VIII (grade 8) and her husband has passed a higher secondary level (grade 12). All of their children are going to school. 

She has her own animal husbandry business where she works very hard to cover the household expenses and her children’s educational expenses. Her husband is a farmer. They are unable to meet their family expenses. Now she decided to grow potatoes on their own farmland to earn more to contribute to her family’s well-being. She applied for a loan to BJS (Kiva’s partner) to buy potato seeds and fertilizers to grow potatoes. She knows that after selling those vegetables in the market, the whole profit will be theirs and then they will be able to extend their business as well as improve her family’s economic condition. Now she is staying in a kaccha house (made of straw and mud) but in the future, she dreams of a pakka (made of bricks and cement) house which is possible only with her business profit and that is why she is very much thankful to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase good quality potato seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Sabita

texts.en:
Sabita is 28 years old, married, and raising two daughters with her husband. Her two daughters are students who are in class IX (Grade 9) and class VII (Grade 7). Her husband Pulok is 37 years old and is a mason. Sabita attended school up to class VII (Grade 7) and her husband received an education up to class VI (Grade 6).  They live in the small village of Molaigram in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri in their own house.

Sabita is a housewife who has a livestock breeding business. Sabita is a very tenacious and hardworking woman. With an aim to develop her business, Sabita has applied for a loan from BJS.  She will buy a dairy cow with the loan and will start the business of milk supply and dairy products (butter, curd, paneer etc.).  She will sell these products in the local market and supply milk from door to door in her locality. She expects a huge profit from the business, as the products are in great demand in the market.

Sabita plans to re-invest the income from her business.  She also plans to save money for the further education of her daughters and build a concrete made house.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Sabitri

texts.en:
Sabitri is 34 years old and married.  She lives with her husband Pulin and two children (one son and one daughter).  Both of her children are students. One is in Grade 5, and the other is in a Montessori school.  They live in their own kachha house (mud, bamboo and straw made). They live in a small village in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri .  Sabitri is illiterate and can only sign her name whereas her husband received an education up to class X (Grade 10).

Sabitri is a housewife and her husband is engaged in agricultural work growing vegetables for more than 10 years.  Now Sabitri has decided to start a potato cultivation business because she noticed that it is a very profitable business and she has land that is suitable for cultivation.  She has decided to sell the crops in the local bazaar and meet her family's expenses and the educational expenses of her children with the profit generated from her business.

She has taken a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner) to purchase potato seeds and manure for growing potatoes.
 
She gives her thanks to the lenders (BJS and Kiva).

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Sandhya

texts.en:
Sandhya is 27 years old, married and has two children (one son and one daughter).  She attended school up to class VI (Grade 6). Her husband Jogodish is 35 years old and has a primary school education.  He works as a laborer under a building contractor.  Both their children are below school-going age.  They live in the small town of Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. They live in their own house.

The earnings of Sandhya's husband are too low to cover all the expenses incurred by their family. So Sandhya is engaged in the business of raising cattle.  She has been in this business more than five years and has a great experience in animal husbandry. Sandhya raises the cattle and her husband helps her by delivering the milk from door to door in their locality.

 Now they have decided to purchase one more cow to increase their existing milk supply business. Sandhya also decided to sell dairy products such as butter, curd, paneer etc. in her locality. To purchase a cow they need some capital so they applied for a loan from BJS (Kiva’s partner).

Sandhya hopes to give a decent lifestyle to her family and save money for the future for the education of her children and to extend the business.  In the future, she wants to buy more cows and build a cattle farm of her own.

Her full thanks go to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Sakuntola

texts.en:
Sakuntola is only 24 years old.  She is from Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri.  She is married and a mother of four children (three sons and one daughter).  Sakuntola lives with her children and husband Bipul in their own semi-pacca house (brick-built wall and thatch roof). She has received an education up to grade 6.  Her only daughter goes to school and reads in grade 4.  All her sons are engaged in business.

Sakuntola's husband is engaged in an agribusiness. His earnings are barely enough to cover all the expenses of the family.  Sakuntola is not lagging behind.  She is trying in her own way to give financial support to the family.  She is engaged in making BIDI (a handmade cigarette, used in rural areas).  Yet they cannot afford a decent lifestyle for their family. So, Sakuntola and her husband decided to start a business cultivating potatoes on their land,

Sakuntola is taking a loan from Kiva’s partner BJS with which she will buy potato seeds and manures for starting her potato cultivation. She will sell the products in the local market where there is a great demand for potatoes.

She gives her thank to the lenders from BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds and manure

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Sunita is a rural woman, 44 years old, who is married to Ashoke, 49 years old. She is illiterate and can only sign her name but her husband is passed class VI (grade 6).They live in Dhupguri in a small kaccha house (made of mud and straw) with their only son. Her son is working as a mason. 

Sunita works in animal husbandry while her husband has a small restaurant in the village. They work hard. Yet they are unable to cover the family’s needs. Sunita decided to give support to her husband financially. She learned that BJS gives loan to rural women to start a business. She applied for that loan to buy a cow to start a dairy products business. Today there is a great demand for dairy products like milk, ghee, curd, cheese, paneer etc. in the village market, so she has a great interest in purchasing a cow to earn more income. Her ambition is to build a pakka house (made of cement and bricks) with the profit from her own business. In the future, she will buy more cows to extend her business on a large scale.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Jayanti

texts.en:
Jayanti, 43, is married and has two children (a daughter and a son). She completed her primary education. She lives with her children and husband Bablu in the small village of Barosoria in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri, in their own house. Her husband, 48, is a farmer by profession and studied up to grade 10.  Both their children go to school and read in grade 10 and grade 6.

The main income-generating activity of her family is the agricultural work of her husband. Jayanti also works hard to support her family economically. She has an animal husbandry business.  Both husband and wife labor hard from dawn to dusk but are unable to give sufficient financial sustenance to the family so, they have decided to start cultivating potatoes.

Jayanti came to know about BJS (Kiva’s partner) and has taken a loan to buy potato seeds and fertilizers to cultivate potatoes. She hopes that she can generate extra income from this business, as it is a profitable one.

She is confident that she will be able to reach her goals and start her new business.  It will not only help her to cover the family's expenses, but she will be able to give her children an opportunity to get an education and establish themselves in life.  She dreams of buying a plot of land with the profit from the business.

Her full thanks go to BJS and Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds and good quality fertilizers

loans.name: Manjuma

texts.en:
Manjuma is married and has four children (two sons and two daughters).Two of her children are in school (Grade 3 and Grade 2, respectively) and two are too young for school. She is 29 years old and a housewife. She is illiterate and can only sign her name. She lives with her children and husband in the small village of Mondirpara in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. They have a semi-pacca (brick-build and straw roof house), which has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest expenses are food and school fees.

Manjuma's husband Hamidul. 31 years old, is also uneducated and can only sign his name. He is engaged in the business of selling firewood. He has been engaged in this business for the past five years. His potential customers are his neighbors. He purchases firewood from his village and neighboring villages and resells it to his customers.  In this way, he earns money for his family, but it is not enough to provide the financial support the family needs.

Mamjuma decided to help her husband to grow his business. She asked for a loan from BJS to purchase more firewood to expand her husband's business so that they will be able to earn a greater profit.

Manjuma hopes this business will enable her to give financial sustenance to her family and better education to her children 

She gives her thanks to her lenders (BJS and Kiva).

loans.use: To purchase firewood to sell

loans.name: Pompi

texts.en:
Pompi is from the small village of Kholaigram in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. She lives with her husband and together they are raising two children (one son and one daughter).  Pompi has an education up to grade 5 but her husband Ukil, 40 years, is illiterate and can only sign his name. They are providing an education to both their children who read in grade 9 and grade 5. They live in their own kachha house (bamboo, mud and straw made).

Her husband is a farmer by profession. He grows different vegetables in different seasons. He sells the agricultural products in the local market, which is an important source of income for her family. Yet they are unable to give a decent lifestyle to their family.

To continue the agribusiness in a sustainable way, Pompi decided to start potato cultivation on their plot of land.  She has taken a loan from BJS to purchase potato seeds and fertilizers.  She has chosen this business because there is a huge demand for the product in the present market.

Her goals are to educate their children in a better way, give good financial support to her family and upgrade their house to a concrete made house in the future

Pompi and her husband are thankful to the lenders (BJS and Kiva) for helping them to maintain their agribusiness.

loans.use: To purchase good quality potato seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Manju

texts.en:
Manju is a house maker from the small village of Altagram in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. She is 43 years old, illiterate, and can only sign her name. She has two children (one son and one daughter).  Both are students in grade 10 and grade 9. Her husband Altaf, who is 47 years old, is engaged in agriculture. They have their own kachha house (bamboo, mud and straw made).

Her husband's agribusiness is the main source of income for their family.  He grows different kinds of vegetables in different seasons and sells them in the local market.  Unfortunately, his income is too low to maintain the family in a decent way. Manju is very energetic and optimistic. She may appear to be a very fragile lady but she is not afraid of any difficulty.
 
She has decided to start potato cultivation on their land but due to a lack of capital, she is unable to start her business. Manju came to know about Kiva’s partner, BJS and asked for a loan to purchase potato seeds and fertilizers. Being a staple vegetable, potatoes are in great demand in the local market.

Manju relies on her own capability and fortune.  She believes that she can start her business and expand it in the future. She aspires to give a good education to her children and give financial stability to her family with the profit generated from the business.

She is thankful to BJS and Kiva for the loan.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Merina

texts.en:
Merina is a 26-year-old housewife from the small village of Barosoria in Dhupguri in the district of Jalpaiguri. She lives with her husband and three children (one son and two daughters).  She passed grade 5. Her husband Faizul, 28 years old, is a farmer.  He is uneducated and can only sign his name. They are providing an education to their children who are in grade 7, grade 3 and grade 1, respectively.

Merina's husband has a plot of ancestral land where he grows different kinds of green vegetables and sells the harvests in the local market. However, his income is so small that they cannot afford a decent living. To be able to cover their daily needs and the educational expenses of their children, Merina has decided to help her husband. To sustain their agribusiness, they need some capital.

She has heard about Kiva’s partner, BJS, who gives loans to rural women for business. She applied for a loan from them to purchase potato seeds and some fertilizers. She has chosen potato cultivation because it is a lucrative business and she hopes to gain much profit from it.

Her goals are to give a financial upgrade to her family, educate her children well and build a pacca house (concrete made) with the profit.

Merina and her husband will be grateful to BJS and Kiva for their support.

loans.use: To purchase potato seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Romarani

texts.en:
Romarani is 43 years old, married, and is raising two sons with her husband. They live in Raipara in Dhupguri in the district Jalpaiguri in their own house. She attended secondary school up to grade 8.  Her husband, Gobindo, is a farmer by profession. He is 51 years old and educated up to grade 8.  Both of her sons are engaged in small business.
